[Galusi]: Now number eight, report on the business services audit of the Metropublic Schools by the Management Solution, TMS, Mr. Andrew Parkett and Mr. David Murphy.

[Galusi]: Hold on, Mr. Murphy, let me just get your microphone on, sorry.

[Galusi]: Thank you, Mr. Murphy.

[Galusi]: Welcome.

[Galusi]: Good evening.

[Galusi]: We're pleased to be here this evening on behalf of TMS to present this report to you.

[Galusi]: I'm Judy Hull.

[Galusi]: I am the Senior Vice President and Chief Education Officer for TMS, and I've been in this business for over 40 years.

[Galusi]: It's a hard number to say.

[Galusi]: But I have been a teacher of students from grades three through adults.

[Galusi]: I've been a curriculum director.

[Galusi]: I've been a business administrator and I've been a superintendent of schools.

[Galusi]: So I've been in most places that education happens.

[Galusi]: So it's nice to be on this side of it and to be able to be a resource to districts as they try to move forward.

[Galusi]: Alan, I'll let you take the next side of honors.

[Galusi]: So the report is broken into two parts.

[Galusi]: The first part is the findings.

[Galusi]: And basically what we did was we combed through the data from the interviews.

[Galusi]: One of us asked the question while the other was the note taker so that we could each focus on our relative tasks around facilitation and note taking to make sure we captured everything.

[Galusi]: And then we looked for common themes that came across from either all or most of the interviews.

[Galusi]: And so that's what you have in the findings piece of this.

[Galusi]: And then the second piece of the report is a set of recommendations around budget development and financial management.

[Galusi]: And these recommendations really stem from state and national organizations as well as TMS's own best practices.

[Galusi]: We have worked in several districts across the Commonwealth and collaboratives as well.

[Galusi]: And so we have learned along the way about what our best practices and how we can make those real for our clients.

[Galusi]: That's where the recommendations stem from.

[Galusi]: So we're gonna start with the findings first.

[Galusi]: And let's talk a little bit about the budget development themes.

[Galusi]: And these were things that were common recurring themes in the interviews that we did with folks.

[Galusi]: And we interviewed about 20 staff members, both on the city side as well as school side and superintendent as well.

[Galusi]: So these are where the themes came along.

[Galusi]: One of the themes that came out in our discussions with folks was that the timeline for putting the budget together seemed to be too late for the kind of presentation, preparation, discussion, and revision that's necessary to put a comprehensive budget together.

[Galusi]: And I think when we get to the recommendations, you'll see why we came to the conclusions we did about that.

[Galusi]: people also felt that prior to the current administration, that there was a lack of input and advocacy for student needs across that.

[Galusi]: They have also reported to us that the current administration is beginning to change that work in the way the budget is developed so that there is input and there is the opportunity to have some advocacy for student needs in the process.

[Galusi]: So I think that's an optimistic sign.

[Galusi]: The other part of the data told us that also because of some high turnover in administrative positions, that some of the history of requests along the way got lost in the shuffle.

[Galusi]: So again, just hopeful that the current administration, as things gel and come together and you have some longevity together, that you're gonna be able to really have some good budget history on which to build.

[Galusi]: And so people really in the interviews seem very optimistic

[Galusi]: about what the future holds for the budget development process.

[Galusi]: And I'll let Alan speak to the financial management themes.

[Galusi]: Just if you could clarify what encumbered means for the community, please.

[Galusi]: Yeah, and it also gives an opportunity for people to see what's left.

[Galusi]: What you pay, what you need to pay, and then what the net is that's left allows you to really calculate and track the budget in a way that makes some sense and to be able to have a software package that can do that for you versus manual calculations

[Galusi]: is certainly gonna be a much more efficient way to be able to do that work.

[Galusi]: Mayor.

[Galusi]: Right.

[Galusi]: And some folks reported that the process for submitting purchase orders and tracking them was different from department to department.

[Galusi]: Again, I think it's because you don't have, at the current moment, an accounting system that can

[Galusi]: take you through that process in a way that is efficient.

[Galusi]: So that was something else that came through in the data as well.

[Galusi]: So those were sort of the major themes that came out of the interviews that we did.

[Galusi]: And so we'll move on now to the recommendations.

[Galusi]: And we'll begin with budget development.

[Galusi]: And it's interesting to

[Galusi]: see and hear that you have a new strategic plan because you stole our thunder a little bit, but that's okay.

[Galusi]: Yes, nice job superintendent, great job.

[Galusi]: So we would recommend an expanded timeline.

[Galusi]: Both of us in our positions as superintendent usually begin this process in November with our administrators.

[Galusi]: We begin that process of looking at where it is that you want to go.

[Galusi]: And aligning the document with your school improvement or your district strategic plan is critical.

[Galusi]: They should fit like a glove.

[Galusi]: You should not have one document over here and another document over here that don't speak to each other.

[Galusi]: Because the only way you're going to be able to accomplish the ambitious goals you've just set for yourselves tonight is to make sure that they are resourced properly so that the things that you have committed to can happen.

[Galusi]: And the only way to do that is to put those two things together.

[Galusi]: So it requires the budget process to begin much earlier in the cycle in to begin November ish, give or take.

[Galusi]: I used to with my principles tell them that their ticket to their December vacation was their budget requests in my hand.

[Galusi]: You know that was often a way to kind of motivate to get the thing done.

[Galusi]: And it's a collaborative process.

[Galusi]: Now that you've got the roadmap in front of you, you really can begin doing a collaborative process on the budget and how all of the pieces impact each other.

[Galusi]: It also allows for accountability in the budget cycle.

[Galusi]: It's a term used in business world, it's called value chain analysis, but you measure the effectiveness of the resources with the metrics for success of goals.

[Galusi]: So we heard repeatedly tonight looking at

[Galusi]: improve student outcomes, and how you measure those student outcomes gives you a window on how the resources are being used to accomplish the goals that you've set for yourselves.

[Galusi]: So it, in a way, puts in its own accountability system within the budget process as well.

[Galusi]: Are the resources we are targeting towards these particular outcomes, are they making a difference?

[Galusi]: And if they're not,

[Galusi]: then how do we need to resource things differently?

[Galusi]: So it's sort of this cyclical process that really keep asking those questions of yourselves.

[Galusi]: Here are the goals we want to accomplish.

[Galusi]: Here are the resources we're gonna put toward it.

[Galusi]: Did we get where we wanted to go with the resources?

[Galusi]: If we did, let's continue moving.

[Galusi]: If we didn't, then we need to think differently about how we do resource allocation.

[Galusi]: So that's all of sort of tonight's presentations kind of wrapped up in one tiny little package in terms of

[Galusi]: how we put those things together.

[Galusi]: And as we think about that, oftentimes people are looking to the business office for how to spend the funds.

[Galusi]: We are not advocates of that.

[Galusi]: We think that the budget belongs in the hands of the people who run the district, most importantly, the people who are closest to the classrooms.

[Galusi]: So your principals, your directors who are really directly involved with the act of teaching and learning, those are the people in whose hands the budget should be.

[Galusi]: What we do in our work is we advise people, we tell you if you have the money or you don't have the money, and we advise you about ways that you can make use of all of the funds that you get, whether it's your local appropriation, any of your grants, those kinds of other resources that are out there, revolving accounts and whatnot, to be able to put those pieces together to get a comprehensive budget picture.

[Galusi]: But it really should be in the hands of the people who are closest to the students.

[Galusi]: So again, that's part of what,

[Galusi]: beginning this process earlier allows to have happen.

[Galusi]: You can take a look at the data.

[Galusi]: How are our kids doing?

[Galusi]: Obviously, you're going to be gathering baseline data right now.

[Galusi]: And then say, OK, what do we want to do in the first year of this strategic plan?

[Galusi]: And what resources do we need to get us to that first year end game?

[Galusi]: And then measure the effectiveness of those resources on that.

[Galusi]: And if things are going well, move forward.

[Galusi]: If they're not, then reassess and reevaluate on that.

[Galusi]: You're on.

[Galusi]: Thanks.

[Galusi]: And it is a long process.

[Galusi]: It will take you probably a good six to 12 months to get this fully up and running.

[Galusi]: So be prepared for that.

[Galusi]: It is arduous.

[Galusi]: And making sure that not only the initial training goes on for staff who are going to be using it, but that there's ongoing training

[Galusi]: that you invest in to make sure that, again, the features that are available through something that's far more robust can be available to you to make the accounting system easier.

[Galusi]: When you have multiple systems, there is opportunity for error.

[Galusi]: There's no way around it.

[Galusi]: And if you're trying to do things like, I have done step and lane changes in a spreadsheet, it is not easy work.

[Galusi]: It's very time consuming.

[Galusi]: an opportunity for error.

[Galusi]: So, you know, the fortunate thing at TMS is we work together as a team.

[Galusi]: So you do your work and you have someone else check it.

[Galusi]: And oftentimes we do find errors if we have to do it manually, because it is just such a difficult task to be able to do.

[Galusi]: So to be able to say to the financial software, can you please roll everybody over and it just does it.

[Galusi]: And you know that the algorithms are in the background to support that work.

[Galusi]: It just makes it a whole lot easier and a whole lot more accurate as well.

[Galusi]: And if there's any one thing we know in this business, it's pay needs to be accurate.

[Galusi]: Absolutely.

[Galusi]: So just some final conclusions from the report.

[Galusi]: You know, as you've gone through tonight's presentations, you are a large and complex district with a diverse student population, certainly.

[Galusi]: But now you have really a strong professional team in place, both at the business office level.

[Galusi]: I can't say enough for your business office staff.

[Galusi]: They're very competent and very,

[Galusi]: caring people.

[Galusi]: They want to do right by the school district and right by the children that you educate.

[Galusi]: They really do.

[Galusi]: So my hat is off to them.

[Galusi]: I think Alan would certainly echo that sentiment as well.

[Galusi]: Very professional, really wanting to do the right thing.

[Galusi]: So you've got now a good administrative team in place that's working collaboratively.

[Galusi]: So I think this is the moment for you to be able to move forward.

[Galusi]: The challenges will be.

[Galusi]: difficult because it is a change of the way of doing business and that's always hard.

[Galusi]: But I think if you're willing to do the work, I think you'll find that, you know, that's going to really just pay off for you in ways that are amazingly wonderful.

[Galusi]: And it was just interesting as I was looking on your website just to see about policies, which your policy manual is in really good place around the business practices.

[Galusi]: So that was not something we had a concern about by any stretch of the imagination.

[Galusi]: But just noticing that, you know, your tagline at the top is that you are curing educational partnership of school, family and community.

[Galusi]: And that's what it will take to be able to just build a really strong school district.

[Galusi]: And I think you're really right on the right path.

[Galusi]: And we hope that this information will help you move forward.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: Member Van der Kloot and Member Graham.

[Galusi]: Member Graham?

[Galusi]: Thank you for your report.

[Galusi]: I just had a couple of clarifying questions.

[Galusi]: Is it standard practice that school committee, school expenditures would require authorization from city hall?

[Galusi]: It's a great question.

[Galusi]: And some of it depends on city charters and how things are written.

[Galusi]: Some of it, again, it's sort of district specific and municipality specific.

[Galusi]: Um, you know, right now we're doing a lot of work for the Greenfield public schools, which is a small city, certainly the size of, by any stretch of the imagination.

[Galusi]: Um, but most of the, um, purchases, you know, daily purchase orders and whatever are processed on the school side with good, what we call in the business internal controls.

[Galusi]: So we have people who put forward requisitions that get signed.

[Galusi]: Um, you know, we have, um,

[Galusi]: bookkeeper who then processes them, sends them to the business administrator, you know, who then verifies and so on and so forth.

[Galusi]: So there's internal controls along the way.

[Galusi]: I think that's the key issue.

[Galusi]: For example, in Greenfield, however, it's a big procurement.

[Galusi]: We work with the city procurement officer to make sure that that process is all done in the way that it should be.

[Galusi]: So I would say that, you know, your city charter may govern some of this.

[Galusi]: you know, not having seen it, I can't speak to that.

[Galusi]: But again, you know, it's how much of the routine things could be done in the school department internally with a good set of internal controls.

[Galusi]: And again, you have a great staff who could certainly provide that check and balance for each other.

[Galusi]: So it's again, how do you put those processes into place to make them work efficiently and well?

[Galusi]: And Mr. Murphy, are you aware whether the charter outlines that as a requirement where the mayor

[Galusi]: I would assume finance laws, but I don't think the charter is only a couple pages long.

[Galusi]: I don't think the charter outlines it.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: And I think the other question or clarification I just wanted from you both is the budget system that you're talking about, is it a requirement that the city and schools would need to implement together

[Galusi]: or is it possible that the school district could pursue an implementation to make its own shop efficient with or serve with or without the city?

[Galusi]: I'm just trying to understand, is it like a package deal?

[Galusi]: Is it recommended to be a package deal?

[Galusi]: And what do you give up if that is not the case?

[Galusi]: And there are reporting requirements obviously on the school side to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education as there are reporting requirements on the municipal side and those do cross paths and end-of-the-year reports so schools are required to report on the city's contribution to the school's efforts and likewise on the municipal side

[Galusi]: the city reports also to the Department of, Division of Local Services, how they're expending funds in the name of the city and also on the school side.

[Galusi]: So having a common software to work with allows for that reporting to be pretty seamless between the city side and the school side.

[Galusi]: Most districts I work in, I've worked in, that is the case that they do share the same platform because it just makes it easier

[Galusi]: again, and more efficient on both sides of the ledger.

[Galusi]: And I just have two more questions, if that's okay.

[Galusi]: So my first question is, you mentioned a six to 12 month implementation window, and as a systems implementer in government, that is like lightning fast.

[Galusi]: So I'm just curious, why is that

[Galusi]: the normal experience of implementing such a software?

[Galusi]: I mean, usually in a complex organization, which certainly the city of Medford qualifies because of all of its disparities across like departments who do completely different things, all kinds of different structures, lots of different like kind of cross sections, like you're looking typically at like 12 to 18.

[Galusi]: Is there a reason why these systems implement so fast?

[Galusi]: Or is that just like the best case scenario?

[Galusi]: Um, probably best case scenario, obviously, the smaller the entity, the shorter the period of time.

[Galusi]: Right now we are working with Windsor Connecticut public schools that just started a implementation process of one of these systems.

[Galusi]: And it's going to be about a year by the time the town and the school department have all of the training and all of the integrations that need to be in a city the size of Medford.

[Galusi]: It could be more like the 12 to 18 month window.

[Galusi]: sure okay thank you and my last question i think is for mr murphy um mr parkett would like to potentially answer one of your questions we already asked so why don't we give him a chance and i'll go back to you mr parkett uh yes good evening everyone uh i apologize for not being able to make it in person um just one of the things i'll say regarding that timeline yes

[Galusi]: And many of the systems now have the ability to easily import what you can export from what you currently have and dump it in.

[Galusi]: And so that does, again, you're not trying to build it from scratch.

[Galusi]: So that's also something that'll be helpful along the way.

[Galusi]: And my last question, you all alluded to lots of things that are already happening because the change of leadership happened earlier this year.

[Galusi]: Is this procurement something that is actively in the works or is this

[Galusi]: not yet moving forward.

[Galusi]: Number nine, introduction of engagement hub initiative.

[Galusi]: Mr. David Murphy and Ms.

[Galusi]: Megan Fidler-Carey.

[Galusi]: Thank you for this opportunity to speak.

[Galusi]: It's really nice to see everybody in person and see everyone's face.

[Galusi]: So this is a really exciting opportunity for me personally, of course, but I think for the district, I think it's just a way to bring together terrific departments that are already working well and working well together, but it's just sort of formalizing the communication between departments.

[Galusi]: It's sort of formalizing, if there's a request for information from one department to the other, I can be there to sort of facilitate the urgency of it, and it's not piling more work on

[Galusi]: and it's making it clearer what's urgent and what's not urgent.

[Galusi]: So I think it's just a way to improve our communications.

[Galusi]: I really like that this presentation is following the strategic plan presentation, because I think that these things dovetail really nicely.

[Galusi]: I think that a lot of the student support is going to be happening here.

[Galusi]: Family engagement happens at every level.

[Galusi]: The principal is doing family engagement in all of their outreach.

[Galusi]: The teachers constantly, the guidance Councilors, adjustment Councilors,

[Galusi]: this new re-engagement team will be there to just sort of fill in some of those cracks, prevent cracks from happening.

[Galusi]: I think, you know, when I, I think you guys have heard me say this before, when I hire for the before and after school program, I always say to them, it just takes that one adult to be the change in any student's life.

[Galusi]: And isn't it exciting that you might be that one adult, you know?

[Galusi]: So if it doesn't happen to be the principal or the teacher or the guidance Councilor, maybe it's somebody from this re-engagement team that will make a connection with the student or make a connection with the family

[Galusi]: to build the necessary trust to re-engage them back into it.

[Galusi]: So I love the idea that we're putting together a team because we'll be able to get people's human strengths and experience and kind of put it together into a nice circle like this, like a puzzle.

[Galusi]: So, you know, we're gonna do that marketing that we mentioned in the, I think that's in the ACE of ACEs, you know, get our marketing together so that we can do a better job of explaining to families what our public schools offer, that they're not getting at charter schools, that they're not getting at parochial schools,

[Galusi]: And I think that that's a way that we can really hyper focus all eight hours of our day and beyond as we all know that you know teachers and people in the schools don't have because they're focused on curriculum instruction as well.

[Galusi]: So we're everybody that we've looked at so far for that's applied for this job has had

[Galusi]: has mentioned social work, has mentioned restorative justice values, and that's really exciting.

[Galusi]: It's all very positive, it's all very strength-based, and it's all really away from that punitive, that truancy officer driving down trying to catch the kid, going to the mall.

[Galusi]: We're totally moved away from that.

[Galusi]: It's really about establishing relationships, figuring out if there's a student not coming to school, figuring out why, and then meeting their needs, connecting them to the resources they need.

[Galusi]: So I'm very excited, I think.

[Galusi]: It's gonna be very successful.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: Thank you very much.

[Galusi]: Member Graham, Member Ruseau, Member McLaughlin, Member Van de Vroegh.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: This is exciting.

[Galusi]: You know, we've talked throughout the budget process about a couple of different things.

[Galusi]: So one is sort of students needing more, especially sort of into

[Galusi]: as we start the next year.

[Galusi]: And we've also talked about the need to revisit our own organizational structure.

[Galusi]: And I feel like this sort of starts to do both of those things at the same time, which is really exciting.

[Galusi]: But I was just curious whether you had received any feedback from the administrative team as you created this and what that feedback was.

[Galusi]: Thank you, Member McLaughlin.

[Galusi]: And Member Van der Kloot.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: Thank you for the presentation.

[Galusi]: It is very exciting.

[Galusi]: It's long overdue.

[Galusi]: Family and community engagement is critical throughout any business and district to engage all your stakeholders.

[Galusi]: You know, I know you said we'll see where we are in a few years, but if we're building relationships, I certainly don't think that we're going to be able to cut them off after a few years.

[Galusi]: So that's encouraging.

[Galusi]: And we'll have to find a way to make sure that we continue this and make this happen.

[Galusi]: But I wanted to ask, I guess, about the interdepartmental collaboration and the tactical team that you're building.

[Galusi]: A few things.

[Galusi]: One is obviously the re-engagement specialist.

[Galusi]: And I wonder if there's, you know, just sort of the name of it, but we're not,

[Galusi]: just thinking preventative, we're thinking proactive.

[Galusi]: And so re-engagement feels like to me, we're talking about, oh, people have become disengaged and now we have to go and re-engage them, right?

[Galusi]: We don't wanna get to that point.

[Galusi]: We wanna be proactive and really start.

[Galusi]: And I know that we have a year that we're reflecting on where people have been disengaged.

[Galusi]: So I just sort of wanna make sure that we're focusing on the proactive and to that end, the school in Maine audit that we were able to have recently.

[Galusi]: and looking at that family and community engagement audit and being able to, it's late in the end of the year and the end of the school year.

[Galusi]: So we had talked about having some sort of presentation around that in September, around what that audit really showed, how we're proactively marrying to our strategic plan in this tactical team would be really great.

[Galusi]: And then obviously I know that you guys are looking at diversity.

[Galusi]: And so we're more thinking about our most vulnerable populations, as you were saying, ensuring that we're reaching them

[Galusi]: you know, through and by people who they identify with, and that we're considering that as we're picking up.

[Galusi]: And I'm sure you are, but I just wanted to, yeah, put that out there.

[Galusi]: Thank you, very exciting.

[Galusi]: You'll notice hyperlinked on the front page of the plan for our strategic improvement is going to be a hyperlink to a glossary of terms.

[Galusi]: This is just a small sample of what would be included in our glossary of terms.

[Galusi]: There are other educational terms that we will be adding to this.

[Galusi]: It is a draft, but just as a sampling to show you some of the terms, just to make sure that the greater community understands all of the language and terminology referenced in our plan.

[Galusi]: We have here the term and then the definition.

[Galusi]: So for example, you can see listed what a 504 plan entails and how you qualify for one.

[Galusi]: terms in terms of positions, you have the BCBA, BTA, the difference between the two.

[Galusi]: And one other example is the credit for life.

[Galusi]: So that is something that happens at the high school level with the junior class for financial literacy.

[Galusi]: So just so that the greater community has an understanding of all of the terms listed in the strategic plan.

[Galusi]: From here, I'm going to kick it off starting the, we're gonna dive into, thank you, the ACEs.

[Galusi]: So the first bucket, the A, is achievement.

[Galusi]: And the objective for the achievement part is to develop and implement strategic wide curricula, instructional strategies, and assessments that allow learners to reach their potential as knowledgeable, ethical, and critical thinking citizens.

[Galusi]: So today, myself and Dr. Riccadeli are going to present the achievement bucket.

[Galusi]: So the first one in achievement, there are four initiatives and I will speak to two and Dr. Riccadeli will speak to two.

[Galusi]: This first one, you'll see it's their listed initiative A1.

[Galusi]: So this is establish an ongoing curriculum review cycle.

[Galusi]: And so the anticipated outcomes for the curriculum review cycle would be to ensure that our curriculum is aligned and updated and current with Massachusetts frameworks.

[Galusi]: Assessing curriculum for bias and professional development to support curriculum.

[Galusi]: Now those are the the broad anticipated outcomes underneath the anticipated outcomes will be action items.

[Galusi]: So just as a brief example.

[Galusi]: For the action items that align to these anticipated outcomes would be right now.

[Galusi]: Currently, we are in the process.

[Galusi]: Many departments are in the process of updating

[Galusi]: their curriculum to the Massachusetts frameworks which have recently been updated so departments such as humanities and fine arts.

[Galusi]: health, world language.

[Galusi]: They're in the process of that now, and the action item would speak to that.

[Galusi]: We're also in the process of vetting and piloting to implement new curriculum based on making sure it's updated with the Massachusetts frameworks.

[Galusi]: Those, as you know from probably some of the budget hearings as well as curriculum subcommittee meetings, we have mathematics, science, and humanities in the process of that.

[Galusi]: Every year, annually, we use a rubric tool to assess our curriculum for bias, and that will continue, and professional development is part of the curriculum review cycle.

[Galusi]: I'm going to now pass it to Dr. Cadell to speak about A2.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: And thank you.

[Galusi]: Now moving to a three.

[Galusi]: So we have the curriculum piece, and we have the instructional piece assessment.

[Galusi]: And so an achievement, a three initiative is to implement common assessments to inform instruction and make modifications to our current curriculum.

[Galusi]: So this is the piece that's going to drive

[Galusi]: a lot of the decision-making in the district.

[Galusi]: And our anticipated outcomes would be how we are utilizing this student data to inform our decisions.

[Galusi]: So that's kind of like the big umbrella piece to this particular initiative.

[Galusi]: So below that is data to better identify student need.

[Galusi]: That is if students that need remediation as well as enrichment.

[Galusi]: Determining the growth.

[Galusi]: and achievement of each individual student.

[Galusi]: And then streamlining and updating our district-wide assessment schedule.

[Galusi]: So what this looks like is we currently have some district-wide assessment pieces that we look at per grade level, per content.

[Galusi]: But we also want to try and work on coming up with a more streamlined district-wide assessment tool.

[Galusi]: that would be common from, let's say, grade three through high school, grade 10 or grade 12.

[Galusi]: That would be common, so we would have a common platform as well as common language amongst educators and administrators.

[Galusi]: This would give us streamlined data so that we could really drill down to the specific needs of our students as well as making sure our curriculum is filling the needs.

[Galusi]: And then the other piece is enhancing and building upon the data teams that we currently have at each of our schools.

[Galusi]: So that especially next year, that's gonna be very important to bridge the gap to this break in instruction that COVID has caused.

[Galusi]: So those are two action items in relation to the anticipated outcomes for assessment.

[Galusi]: And there's one more initiative in achievement, Dr. Riccadeli.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: Now it's back to Dr. Cushing and Mr. Tucci.

[Galusi]: Well, I see the superintendent's hand.

[Galusi]: I'll defer to her, and then I'll follow up if.

[Galusi]: I just personally wanted to say that the coaching to me is the

[Galusi]: more of the key point in working with the staff.

[Galusi]: The interventionist, to me, is a structural piece that is a very delicate balance when it comes to mathematics, because we don't want to put interventionists to pull students out of a math lesson that they're going to miss core content.

[Galusi]: And right now, if you have the coaching to work with the teachers on part of the math curriculum,

[Galusi]: like we were talking about, the interventionist piece is a little bit more of the scheduling and the structural piece of how to have interventionists be effective and actually compliment the math lesson.

[Galusi]: I don't know if you're understanding what I'm saying, but when a teacher has a math lesson for 60 to 75 minutes, it's really not, at the elementary level, it's really not all that

[Galusi]: effective to remove students from the class for intervention.

[Galusi]: They need to be there for the lesson, the activities that follow, the review.

[Galusi]: We have to build up the structure, especially coming out of COVID, where the successful piece of using an interventionist would be pushing into the classroom.

[Galusi]: And for next year, where there's going to be three, maybe four, but at least three different math programs going on, it's not the best use of staff.

[Galusi]: Um, I just wanted to say, of course, there'll be a somewhat of a void in losing the Italian program but I do want to be mindful that

[Galusi]: What we're putting in place moving forward for the additional specialist program for students is based on the current need right now coming out of a global pandemic.

[Galusi]: And what students need right now is a little bit more concentrated and extended focus on social emotional skills, as well as developing some of those executive functioning skills that were lost in these past 14 to 15 months.

[Galusi]: And I do wanna say that

[Galusi]: And I'm not minimizing at all the Italian program, but it also did not service every student in the building.

[Galusi]: And this fifth additional special will service every student in the building, especially at this moment in time.

[Galusi]: And I also wanted to mention in reference to your question, member Van der Kloot, that a lot of what you're talking about in that void, that is woven into all of the ELA curriculum, the social studies curriculum.

[Galusi]: It's embedded in part of the responsive classroom and the content that the teachers focus on in morning meeting.

[Galusi]: and as well as the addition of all of the cultural proficiency work that we're doing with staff and bringing into the classrooms every day.

[Galusi]: So that kind of global piece, though it may not be answered by what the Italian program did, but it actually, in all of the other areas of the day, it's more of a broader scope.

[Galusi]: We're going to have to hire some new staff for that position.

[Galusi]: I just wanted to clarify to member Rousseau's comment that just in certain situations, the principals work with families when these videos come up.

[Galusi]: If there are students that are transitioning or transgender, the students are choosing the,

[Galusi]: puberty video that they want to participate in and that they relate with.

[Galusi]: So I just wanted to make that clear.

[Galusi]: Yes, the nurses typically still give it to the girls and the PE teachers will give it to the boys or they'll separate them out that way.

[Galusi]: But students are able to choose which video they most relate to.

[Galusi]: Yes, perfect.

[Galusi]: That was a wonderful segue, Mr. Murphy.

[Galusi]: Thank you very much.

[Galusi]: Before I start talking about the elementary school principals, I'm just going to introduce the elementary representative that will be speaking on behalf of the principals and that is Mr. Kirk Johnson.

[Galusi]: If he could just unmute for a minute just to address the school committee.

[Galusi]: Once that happens, I will move on to the elementary school priorities.

[Galusi]: Thank you, Mr. Johnson.

[Galusi]: So a result of that collaborative process are the key priorities that we have displayed here.

[Galusi]: So I'm just going to explain each one of them.

[Galusi]: And if there are any questions, just please let me know.

[Galusi]: So the first key priority at the elementary level is grade level paraprofessionals to ensure more inclusive programming.

[Galusi]: That is just to ensure the needs of students and to support them next year, no matter the setting.

[Galusi]: So these are grade level paraprofessionals that could be supporting students in special education, but also supporting students in general education.

[Galusi]: We know that students are going to have needs that are academic as well as social emotional, and having some additional support next year will be very instrumental.

[Galusi]: The next piece is the reading intervention specialist.

[Galusi]: So what we know will be needed next year is a little bit more support in terms of intervention.

[Galusi]: Having additional reading interventionists, especially to target those foundational years that were interrupted

[Galusi]: two years in a row.

[Galusi]: So what would be next year's second grade and third grade will be really key in making sure that we are giving the interventions and the supports to students that are having a little bit more difficulty closing that gap.

[Galusi]: Building-based professional development, that's something that I'm really excited to see part of the budget this year.

[Galusi]: As you know, it's something that's important for principals to be able to have some professional development funding in every year, but especially coming out of COVID.

[Galusi]: This will allow principals to be able to use some funding

[Galusi]: that will specifically target some training and professional development within their school buildings, which will be a little bit more drilled down and focused than district-wide professional development.

[Galusi]: Increased adjustment Councilor services.

[Galusi]: So in my work with Stacey Shulman and in speaking with her, this is something that she's also looking to do, which she'll probably report to you on later on in the week.

[Galusi]: What she's doing right now is she's reevaluating the support levels at each and every school and going to make sure that they are streamed line for support.

[Galusi]: instituting additional specials programming responsive to COVID-19.

[Galusi]: So as you're aware, Italian is no more, and at the elementary level, we will be needing a fifth special.

[Galusi]: Thank you, Mr. Murphy.

[Galusi]: You are correct.

[Galusi]: So this year it was not a factor in terms of scheduling for students within buildings because of the remote academy and we were able to staff remote academy specialists.

[Galusi]: And that way students were able to get what they need and the schedule in the buildings were able to proceed.

[Galusi]: Next year in response to everything that is happening, I am also working with Stacey Shulman as well as some principals.

[Galusi]: And we are going to be working on a fifth special

[Galusi]: that will target specifically the COVID related needs of students.

[Galusi]: That means we are looking to make sure that we are supporting students' social emotional needs, health needs, and executive functioning needs.

[Galusi]: One of the things this year that I've tried to really make a priority is getting to the schools and speaking with students and speaking with staff.

[Galusi]: I also surveyed staff in regards to the fifth special and where they feel the needs are.

[Galusi]: And it was kind of overwhelming the supports that the educators feel that would benefit students next year is giving them a little bit more time focused specifically on learning and academics so that the SEL needs are continuing throughout the entire day.

[Galusi]: Also with a little focus on executive functioning skills that may have been lost this year.

[Galusi]: Finally, the Zaner-Blauser program, which I know was presented to the school committee prior to COVID and was part of our initial budget needs before COVID hit in March, that's circling back again.

[Galusi]: As you are aware, if not, just a little refresher, Jan Hollenbeck worked with the principals and assistant principals for the past year or two.

[Galusi]: trying to get the Xenoblazer program here, which would be a focus of printing in K1 with a refresher in grade two, and a cursive writing program for grades three and four.

[Galusi]: And that covers the elementary priorities.

[Galusi]: If you have any questions.

[Galusi]: You're doing such a great job there, Mr. Murphy.

[Galusi]: Um, all I would say is that I think in listening to people speak this evening, the SEL thread starts in pre K and goes all the way through 12th grade.

[Galusi]: One of the curriculums that we have at the elementary level is also zones of regulation.

[Galusi]: And if students aren't in the green zone and their social emotional needs are not taken care of, then they're not going to be ready to learn.

[Galusi]: And so we know, I mean, I'm a mother myself, I have two very different students.

[Galusi]: And one fits very nicely inside the box and has done well.

[Galusi]: the past year and a half and one of my children is not even anywhere near that box and has had, you know, her struggles.

[Galusi]: And so I think we know that when students come back to school, they're all going to be at different places.

[Galusi]: And part of this special is going to focus on those social emotional needs, in addition to what teachers are doing on a daily basis, six hours that they have those students.

[Galusi]: but also weave in some of the executive functioning skills that were missed and lost during children being at home.

[Galusi]: And part of those executive functioning skills are also social skills.

[Galusi]: It's not just the executive functioning skills that relate to academics.

[Galusi]: Some of those are the social skills that will also be worked and enhanced.

[Galusi]: The other piece that I do wanna say where there is somewhat of an unknown for next year,

[Galusi]: Currently right now, and you know the principals could speak to this as well, but I know many of the grades, especially on nice weather days, they're taking the students outside for a snack.

[Galusi]: It's an opportunity to have another mask break.

[Galusi]: It's also an opportunity to get some fresh air and after the recess run around for a little bit and get that kind of

[Galusi]: second burst that you're talking about, member Ruseau, I would imagine that if we are, time and learning is very important, but if we're also returning next year with masks still in place, a similar schedule and requirement is still going to be happening where we're going to take those opportunities for lessons as well as snack to be outdoors.

[Galusi]: But could I also just add on that, um, Dr. K just let me know that the tiles actually were already fixed.

[Galusi]: That illustrates what Mr. Murphy was talking about when these things come up, they're just addressed.

[Galusi]: about now.

[Galusi]: No.

[Galusi]: Is this the time that you want to hear it?

[Galusi]: So in Q4 of 2020, you've all seen the house on the corner of Forest Street and Westfield Road that was blighted for many years.

[Galusi]: It's been being renovated, and after sinking all that money into the property, there was a day that city workers were installing a speed trap directly in front of the house.

[Galusi]: The owner asked them not to do it, and in so many words was told, too bad.

[Galusi]: I did reach out to Mr. Caraviello.

[Galusi]: He spoke with the traffic engineer.

[Galusi]: We were told that this was going to be addressed.

[Galusi]: It never got addressed.

[Galusi]: It is still sitting in front of this house, and it's directly in front of the door.

[Galusi]: And I actually have a... Somebody wants to take these.

[Galusi]: I have pictures for all of you that kind of show you exactly what's going on.

[Galusi]: This B-trap, you stand in the master bedroom of one of these units, and I actually didn't know about it being installed that day.

[Galusi]: I was upstairs in the master bedroom, and I see this flashing light.

[Galusi]: It's this B-trap in front of the house.

[Galusi]: When I went to the other unit, I'm standing in the living room, and you see this flashing light.

[Galusi]: That is not fair.

[Galusi]: If you guys all know Forest Street, he could have gone down a couple of houses.

[Galusi]: And you have houses that are set way back from the street.

[Galusi]: That speed trap could have been put there.

[Galusi]: It wouldn't have bothered anybody.

[Galusi]: He could have gone up a couple of blocks.

[Galusi]: It could have been installed in front of the houses that are up off of Forest Street.

[Galusi]: It wouldn't have bothered anybody.

[Galusi]: On the flip side of that paper that I just gave you is Highland Avenue.

[Galusi]: So 914 Highland Avenue, that buyer paid $800,000 for that house.

[Galusi]: And now the city of Medford has installed a crosswalk with a traffic light and another structure right there for you to press the button, not just in front of the property, but directly in front of the front door.

[Galusi]: Nine houses down, the same exact thing was installed.

[Galusi]: So you guys all know how the job there's a lot of places this stuff could have gone.

[Galusi]: I don't understand why we need to have a nine house away.

[Galusi]: I mean, we're all pretty healthy people here.

[Galusi]: But

[Galusi]: And to put it in front of somebody's front door is to encumber their residence, but also to devalue their property.

[Galusi]: I did try to take this up over the course of the last two days.

[Galusi]: Thank you, Mr. Mark, Mr. Caraviello.

[Galusi]: I would include you in those emails to numerous people in this city, because I don't know who to address it to.

[Galusi]: And the answer that I got from the traffic engineer today

[Galusi]: It was a beautiful email, but it didn't address the situation on why we're doing this for our residents.

[Galusi]: So I'm coming tonight to the council to ask for your assistance in resolving this, because it's totally changing the landscape of Medford.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: I just wanted to follow up on the superintendent's comments just to kind of mentioned at the beginning, you know, Jesse's guidance was for districts to give another survey.

[Galusi]: We are always guided by what is best for students, even though sometimes some people may feel that.

[Galusi]: Maybe that's not at the core, but that really is at the core of what we're doing, which is why we're making this a very personal decision.

[Galusi]: So we want the conversation to be held at the principal level, not in a simple black and white survey.

[Galusi]: This way conversations can happen so that the principals can assure that parents are not feeling

[Galusi]: bullied or pressured into making the decision.

[Galusi]: There is not a petition that's being given to the principal.

[Galusi]: It is a one-on-one conversation.

[Galusi]: We also know that two-thirds or even a little bit more than two-thirds of the year have already passed where students have built positive rapports with their teacher.

[Galusi]: We do not want to disrupt that rapport.

[Galusi]: In my meeting today with the principals, as of right now, we're able to absorb it.

[Galusi]: It is really in just an extreme situation that the superintendent just has to put that.

[Galusi]: people in Stacy's department Councilors use with staff is it's utilized every day as part of morning meeting and is throughout the day and if you're not in the green zone you're not ready to learn and so that's a big focus especially k-2 but it is utilized throughout elementary.

[Galusi]: So, students in every elementary school are starting the day in a morning meeting, which the whole entire focus of morning meeting is on the social emotional well being of students and building a supportive culture in every classroom.

[Galusi]: make sure that that continues next year.

[Galusi]: All right, good evening.

[Galusi]: As Dr. Cushing earlier said, my name is Suzanne Galusi.

[Galusi]: I'm the assistant superintendent of elementary education.

[Galusi]: So I'm just going to provide a few little updates that we've been working on this summer.

[Galusi]: So first, our big focus district-wide, which Dr. Cushing will talk about too in a little bit, but our big focus this year is SEL.

[Galusi]: which means social-emotional learning, and starting the year so that we are creating supportive, engaged, and collaborative learning environments for our students.

[Galusi]: At the elementary level, that means responsive classroom, which I've spoken about before in forums such as this, school committee meetings, and in my updates that I send to families.

[Galusi]: But responsive classroom, we are going to focus on this.

[Galusi]: In part of that program, there's something that's called the first six weeks.

[Galusi]: In Medford, we're kind of doing it as the first three weeks.

[Galusi]: But the first three weeks of school are going to work on those skills that are going to lay the foundation for that learning environment that's going to carry through for the entire year.

[Galusi]: So it is a time to build the classroom community, build positive, safe,

[Galusi]: relationships within that classroom and work on expectations.

[Galusi]: It's a time for the teacher and the students to work on how they want the learning environment to be for the year and going through the expectations for every block of the day.

[Galusi]: So what does it look like?

[Galusi]: What does it sound like?

[Galusi]: How should we be when it's math class, when it's writing class, when it's science class, and working with students so that they're aware of what the expectations are throughout the day.

[Galusi]: will have them in a very good position to know how the day is going to be for them and then how the year will carry on.

[Galusi]: When we lay the foundation like this at the beginning of the year,

[Galusi]: There's less disruption to the learning and there's more engagement on the students part.

[Galusi]: It also builds trust and empathy, which are skills that we want not only for learners, but for humans in life.

[Galusi]: This summer, we

[Galusi]: Well, at the end of the year, we created at every building a responsive classroom support team.

[Galusi]: So there are teachers at every building that are going to be the touch point for that school building when it comes to responsive classroom and social emotional learning.

[Galusi]: Those teachers engaged in a week-long responsive classroom training this summer.

[Galusi]: Out of that group of trainers, two of them this week gave some training on responsive classroom to new teachers so that they're ready to start next week understanding our expectations for responsive classroom and that initiative here at Medford Public Schools.

[Galusi]: They will also be providing district training throughout the year.

[Galusi]: Another exciting piece, as we have mentioned last year, but I will mention it again now, is we have an additional special for the students this year.

[Galusi]: So that means there will be five offerings for students as a special activity.

[Galusi]: So there's art, and there's music, there's technology, there's physical education, and now there's Nexus.

[Galusi]: Nexus is a class that is going to target age-appropriate skills for students in social-emotional learning and executive functioning.

[Galusi]: So we're going to re-engage students in school and hone on those skills that are the social skills that are going to help them navigate school again, and also work on some of those executive functioning skills that are necessary for the grade level.

[Galusi]: We've partnered with Hill for Literacy.

[Galusi]: It is a group we've partnered with before, but this year Hill for Literacy is going to be coming in every month and working with our K-2 staff on their ECRI program, which is Enhanced Core Reading Instruction.

[Galusi]: It is based on the science of reading and we're so very happy and honored that they're going to be working with us this year.

[Galusi]: I'll be sending out more detailed information about that to families as we begin.

[Galusi]: And then the last piece I just wanted to mention is, I'm sure it's top of mind for everyone, but principals have been working all summer alongside me planning for this year.

[Galusi]: And they've put in lots of hours, but I wanted to let you know that when

[Galusi]: It comes to school-based routines.

[Galusi]: So how is it going to be at arrival or dismissal, lunch, the schedule of the building?

[Galusi]: All of that will be shared by principals prior to the first day of school.

[Galusi]: But I do want families to know that at the elementary level, there will be two separate locations for lunchtime.

[Galusi]: That way we can split up each lunch period and ensure that we are socially distancing students during lunchtime.

[Galusi]: Um, please email me if yo or give me a call.

[Galusi]: I'm h any questions or concerns you very much and we do look

[Galusi]: Yes, we can.

[Galusi]: That's a good suggestion, Dr. Cushing.

[Galusi]: I think Mr. Murphy should start over with the update on the Teachers Association.

[Galusi]: Sure.

[Galusi]: I think the only thing that I would mention is that, um, if students have to be at home, um, for any reason, work would be provided and communication between the teacher and the student and family, um, would just occur throughout the week, um, as a, as a way.

[Galusi]: And then when the student returns to school, any type of assistance or help remediation, um, enrichment, what have you would take place between the family and the teacher.

[Galusi]: I'd like to just address the outside eating at the elementary level, because it does differ at the elementary level than the secondary level.

[Galusi]: I will say that snack is always an option outside.

[Galusi]: Many teachers took that opportunity last year to get the class outside for a needed mask break, a movement break, and to have their snack outside.

[Galusi]: Lunch is a different situation for various reasons.

[Galusi]: One, it definitely is a coverage issue.

[Galusi]: That's when teachers eat their lunch.

[Galusi]: And when it's lunchtime, there are several classes eating at the same time.

[Galusi]: And we do have some students that also would not be able to have their lunch outside.

[Galusi]: And so for varying and at the same time, different classrooms are having recess.

[Galusi]: on those grounds when some classrooms have their lunchtime.

[Galusi]: And not every school has attached land where it would be possible to put up a tent or try to figure out, even if we had the coverage, to try to figure out an outdoor space.

[Galusi]: So there's very varying logistical reasons at the elementary level where the students are a little bit older at the secondary level and more independent.

[Galusi]: during that meal time, that it's a little bit more feasible.

[Galusi]: But at this time, snack absolutely can be outside, but lunch is going to be indoors.

[Galusi]: No, I think I gave an update at the beginning.

[Galusi]: I think I would just echo what Ms.

[Galusi]: Bowen said.

[Galusi]: We've definitely been working all summer long, getting ready.

[Galusi]: We're very excited to see the students return.

[Galusi]: It was wonderful to have the summer camps, Dr. Cushing and I and Ms.

[Galusi]: Bowen, as we went for the acceleration camps and Camp Mustang.

[Galusi]: A lot of people very excited and very happy to welcome students back and transition them to a new school year.

[Galusi]: So we're very grateful for that.

[Galusi]: And if there's any, you know, questions, please feel free to reach out.

[Galusi]: Yeah, I just want to say I do have just a little bit of concern though in terms of the close contact information because there are there are in every building scenarios and more than one situation where the close contact information has nothing to do with Medford public schools.

[Galusi]: and contact with a positive person within Medford public schools.

[Galusi]: People are quarantining as well from being close contacts to family members at home, or in their hometown districts and that would skew the information that parents

[Galusi]: you know, are gonna be going to look at to help make their decisions.

[Galusi]: And so I'm a little concerned using the close contact information.

[Galusi]: With that being said, I think that that's the difficulty right now in some of the, you know, concerns that people are bringing up with coverage issues, because that's the kind of umbrella or domino effect that is occurring right now, which the positive rates might be a little low, but the close coverages are a little high.

[Galusi]: So I just needed to say that because the numbers won't be completely valid

[Galusi]: unless we're just reporting on close contacts that are in relationship to Metro Public Schools.

[Galusi]: Yep, just point of clarification.

[Galusi]: The surveys were to be out by tomorrow morning.

[Galusi]: They're due next Tuesday, December 15th.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: I think so, yes.

[Galusi]: Thank you very much.

[Galusi]: I'm just going to have, if Dr. Cushing doesn't mind sharing his screen, I think we had a little.

[Galusi]: I can just start by saying, I'll just start off by saying good evening.

[Galusi]: Tonight, Stacey Shulman and I are going to be presenting a report on the Responsive Classroom Program at the elementary school level.

[Galusi]: When the closure hit in March, I was the principal at the Brooks School at the time.

[Galusi]: And the biggest message that I gave to my staff was centered around social emotional well-being.

[Galusi]: I knew at that time that we needed to keep

[Galusi]: students anchored to school, and that keeping them engaged in school was going to mean that they stayed connected, connected to their student, to their classmates, connected to their teachers, and that during this pandemic was the most important thing.

[Galusi]: And so around, since the Brooks School was and is a responsive classroom school, the staff was trained

[Galusi]: in the program and time was built into the schedule for morning meeting.

[Galusi]: So maintaining the morning meeting time, even virtually, wasn't too much of a heavy lift and it ensured that we were able to keep kids connected.

[Galusi]: And around that time, Stacey Shulman and I connected over and planning for the social emotional wave that we just anticipated was

[Galusi]: coming our way as a result of COVID.

[Galusi]: And so we started talking about responsive classroom and the implementation of it at the elementary level district wide.

[Galusi]: And with that being said, I'm going to pass it off to Stacey just to frame it a little bit.

[Galusi]: Our work.

[Galusi]: So responsive classroom it's an approach it's not specifically a program, you know, or necessarily a curriculum it's often used in collaboration with other programs.

[Galusi]: So there are some schools in the district, particularly the Columbus that is a PBS school positive behavior support.

[Galusi]: that works in conjunction with responsive classroom and even at the Brooks there were elements of PBIS woven into the responsive classroom approach.

[Galusi]: We also use zones of regulation within the Medford public schools and both programs work really nicely together.

[Galusi]: So responsive classroom is an approach where there is a belief that children learn best

[Galusi]: when we're developing their social-emotional skills as well as their academic skills.

[Galusi]: And there's a lot to be said for that, especially as mentioned before about the zones of regulation, which is true that students can't really learn if they're not in the green zone, if they're not feeling safe and comfortable.

[Galusi]: You need the social-emotional development of skills in order to really be able to focus on the academic skills that students need in school.

[Galusi]: Next slide please.

[Galusi]: Okay, so the responsive classroom has many components to it, where we've done the training on a lot of these components, but not all of these components and we're just the beginning here.

[Galusi]: So some of the components of responsive classroom is morning meeting.

[Galusi]: in which if there are parents or educators on this call, you know that at the elementary level, whether it's the hybrid learning model or the remote academy, students are starting their day in a morning meeting.

[Galusi]: This is a time for the class to gather together and work to build that positive culture.

[Galusi]: that is going to support learning.

[Galusi]: It's also what's nice about starting the day with morning meeting is it gives a structured routine that students desperately crave all the time, but especially right now during COVID.

[Galusi]: That also part of the,

[Galusi]: real important piece of responsive classroom is the rules creation, which really should be done in collaboration with the students.

[Galusi]: That makes the students feel like they have a voice in how they're going to feel safe within the classroom and build collaboration with their peers.

[Galusi]: It also creates instant buy-in when they feel that they have a piece of creating the rules of the classroom.

[Galusi]: The interactive modeling is extremely important.

[Galusi]: I'm going to get into that a little bit in the next slide, not yet.

[Galusi]: But when we talk about one of the trainings that the teachers had, which was on the first six weeks, in order for students to truly understand what both the social emotional skills that we're trying to develop in students

[Galusi]: and the academic skills, what they look like, what they sound like within a classroom, you need to have modeling.

[Galusi]: Students need to see it.

[Galusi]: They need to hear it in order for them to truly understand what is being expected of them.

[Galusi]: Another component is a positive teacher language.

[Galusi]: This is an approach to making sure that when adults are interacting with other adults and when adults are interacting with students, we're mindful of the tone we use and the words and language we use when we're speaking to people.

[Galusi]: And so there's a lot of training around being more aware and cognizant of the actual words we're using when we're interacting with big people and little people.

[Galusi]: And then logical consequences piece so inevitably, in any situation, there are going to be some misbehaviors and some challenging behaviors and making sure that our consequences are aligned to that behavior.

[Galusi]: makes it logical and makes it more, it has more of an impact on students if we're dealing with those misbehaviors in a way that's tied to the direct behavior.

[Galusi]: That is going to make the connection for the student as to hopefully in the next time, the learning is there as to why their behavior was not appropriate.

[Galusi]: Next slide please.

[Galusi]: So the first training that staff received and the way that the responsive classroom starts the year is a program or an approach called the first six weeks.

[Galusi]: The first six weeks is the foundation to a successful school year.

[Galusi]: It's like the building blocks.

[Galusi]: So at the Brooks School, we gave pretty much the month of September to the first six weeks in laying the groundwork for what the school year was going to look like, both

[Galusi]: for the social emotional skill development and the academic skill development.

[Galusi]: We gave our Medford Public Schools teachers this year the same time so that they could create their classroom environment and set of expectations so that come October 1st, we could hit the ground running and those sorts of routines and behaviors and expectations were already set.

[Galusi]: This is the time where that modeling is so crucial.

[Galusi]: So that teachers, you have this time for teachers to introduce students to their peers, to the building, to their teacher, to the space within the classroom, and to the expectations for learning within the classroom, whether it's virtual or in person.

[Galusi]: The first six weeks is when you're modeling.

[Galusi]: What does it look like?

[Galusi]: What does it sound like when we have math class?

[Galusi]: What does it look like?

[Galusi]: What does it sound like when you're working with peers collaboratively?

[Galusi]: What does it look like?

[Galusi]: What does it sound like when we have to walk out to recess or to specials?

[Galusi]: What does it look like, sound like to

[Galusi]: during writing block.

[Galusi]: All of the routines of the school day and all of the expectations around behavior and academics happen within what's called the first six weeks.

[Galusi]: And then the next slide is the second training that staff had, and that for some of us is new, is the morning meeting block.

[Galusi]: So morning meeting, as mentioned, is that predictable time for students.

[Galusi]: It's a time where you build on your community and a time where students can feel safe.

[Galusi]: There are four components to morning meeting.

[Galusi]: Most feel that it should keep this, which is why they're numbered 1, 2, 3, 4.

[Galusi]: It should keep that order.

[Galusi]: But there's definite flexibility to whatever works in the classroom.

[Galusi]: So the most morning meetings start with a greeting.

[Galusi]: And so there's several ways you can do this and lots of creative, fun ways.

[Galusi]: A lot of times in the first six weeks, teachers will maybe review all those different ways that you could greet one another.

[Galusi]: This year, I know as part of the training, those four fabulous trainers that Ms.

[Galusi]: Schulman mentioned also gave some adaptations for how things could be done now that we have to keep six feet of social distancing.

[Galusi]: So, you know, we can't do the hand shaking anymore.

[Galusi]: And some of the greetings that we typically have done in the past

[Galusi]: had to be a little bit more adapted this year to six feet.

[Galusi]: The second piece is the sharing, which usually there's a schedule for this so that throughout the week, every student has the opportunity to share.

[Galusi]: Now, not only does this build bonds of a classroom, but it also teaches students how to be active and engaged

[Galusi]: participants, as well as those skills in presenting and listening to feedback from their classmates when they're asking questions.

[Galusi]: The group activity portion has lots of flexibility.

[Galusi]: So it can be seen in an academic activity.

[Galusi]: It could be seen in a game, which is a little bit more fun, the reciting of a poem.

[Galusi]: It could also be seen if you draw your attention to the top picture that was in a fourth grade classroom at the McGlynn school and during their group activity on Fridays.

[Galusi]: It might be more than one day, but you'll see that the students in the in the classroom as well.

[Galusi]: Well, you might not be able to see the students on the screen, but they each have a book of the one that's displayed here.

[Galusi]: And they listen to it collectively as a class, but through audio recording of the story.

[Galusi]: And so this was happening during the group activity portion of morning meeting.

[Galusi]: And then finally is the morning message, which the teacher will write to the students.

[Galusi]: It can contain a riddle or something fun and exciting that's coming up for the day, or it could just be a review of the schedule.

[Galusi]: In the bottom picture, this is a kindergarten at the Brooks.

[Galusi]: You'll see that off to the right a little bit is an easel.

[Galusi]: It does contain the morning message that the teacher will review right before the close of morning meeting.

[Galusi]: I think at this point, I'm gonna send it back to Stacey Shulman to go over the survey results from the staff.

[Galusi]: Yes, so our next steps are

[Galusi]: Responsive classroom is not just for this COVID academic year.

[Galusi]: Responsive classroom will continue for next year at each elementary school.

[Galusi]: And we will continue to have time built into the schedule so that teachers are able to have a morning meeting with their entire classroom.

[Galusi]: Part of the schedule just for parents that are on this call that may not be aware is that the morning meeting time

[Galusi]: that is built in at the very beginning of the day ensures that the rest of the school schedule in terms of specialists pull out services that starts after the morning meeting time which makes sure that every single student is able to start their day with his or her peers are training and coaching sessions are going to be continued to be provided for staff.

[Galusi]: We are looking to increase the number of trainers.

[Galusi]: So maybe if anyone's interested, they could email Stacey Shulman or myself.

[Galusi]: It's so much fun.

[Galusi]: And then we really would like, we're looking into expanding the training to include the power of our words, which is the piece that I was speaking about before about the language that

[Galusi]: the adults are using when they're having conversations with other adults as well as with the students.

[Galusi]: And then there is more information here at the link for responsive classroom.

[Galusi]: We will post this report to the Medford Public Schools website after this school committee meeting for those at home that want to be able to review the slides and maybe have the link accessible there.

[Galusi]: And Ms.

[Galusi]: Schulman, thank you very much.

[Galusi]: And Ms.

[Galusi]: Schulman and I are ready for any questions that you may have.

[Galusi]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Galusi]: I also think that some of that work also started with some of the task force meetings over the summer.

[Galusi]: So part of one of the task forces over the summer in the reopening of schools was geared towards specifically communication and working in that effort to keep the community informed of all of our reopening efforts and what we're doing to make sure that

[Galusi]: the community is safe and that we're reopening our schools and all the work that went into that and some of that work has continued in the fact that we have, you know, made sure that the superintendent sends out her weekly communication on Fridays and that's something that the community now has gotten

[Galusi]: used to seeing and expecting on Fridays, Wednesdays are the commercial day.

[Galusi]: So I think there are some goals that maybe started over the summer that have also continued a little bit throughout the year during this COVID time, as Mr. Murphy said.

[Galusi]: So they don't have access the way that middle school and high school does because the teachers don't record their grades within school brains.

[Galusi]: They use it to do their report cards, but they don't upload grades and assignments in school brains the way that the secondary level does.

[Galusi]: So parents do have access to go in and edit.

[Galusi]: So if they've made, if they have a different phone number or things like that, they can edit their personal demographics, but they're not going to be able to see their children's grades the way that the secondary level will.

[Galusi]: No, when it comes to the elementary level, I think that that is something this year that Kim Miles has been working now that she's fully the one that's working with the school brains.

[Galusi]: She has been working on that with the school brains company so that we can get to the point where elementary families are able to edit their own personal information.

[Galusi]: As of right now, it's done by the school based secretaries.

[Galusi]: Got it.

[Galusi]: And so

[Galusi]: Right, so if a parent is not, exactly what Dr. Cushing said.

[Galusi]: So if a parent is not receiving an email or robocall from the district, then the first step needs to be working at the school-based level with the secretary to see why.

[Galusi]: So if it's that they've changed their phone number, their email, there's a typo.

[Galusi]: I will say there have been instances in the past where families have maybe knowingly or unknowingly

[Galusi]: um, you know, marked school emails in like spam or something.

[Galusi]: And so they directly go there or they're directly removed from their emails.

[Galusi]: And so there have been a few instances where some of our, um, communication staff here have had to restore, um, so that they will accept again, the school emails.

[Galusi]: Yeah, very nice.

[Galusi]: Anyway, let's see, who else is here?

[Galusi]: is having the opportunity to be a part of this training.
