[Galusi]: Good evening.

[Galusi]: Thank you very much.

[Galusi]: Okay, so Dr. Cushing and I are going to report on the Metro Public Schools remote learning models, and we're going to start with the elementary.

[Galusi]: So at the elementary, thank you, at the elementary level, we refer to the remote model as the remote academy.

[Galusi]: That is mostly because at the elementary level, every school building has a remote academy strand that runs within the school building.

[Galusi]: So for each of the four elementary schools, there is at least one classroom

[Galusi]: for grades K through five that has the remote academy students present in it.

[Galusi]: Each remote academy classroom is comprised of Medford Public Schools employees and teachers.

[Galusi]: That's a big piece where some school systems were unable to house a remote academy for the district using district staff.

[Galusi]: A lot of them have housed that out to online platforms.

[Galusi]: And I think it's very important that we've done that with our Medford Public Schools staff.

[Galusi]: We are continuing to follow the Medford Public Schools remote schedule as it was established on the first day of school.

[Galusi]: For children that are enrolled in the remote academy,

[Galusi]: They work with their teacher virtually.

[Galusi]: Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday is a full day of virtual school.

[Galusi]: And so students log on from 8.30 to 2.30, following the schedule with their teacher.

[Galusi]: It is a mix of synchronous and asynchronous time.

[Galusi]: And Wednesday is a half day of virtual school.

[Galusi]: You can go to the next slide, Dr. Cushing, thank you.

[Galusi]: So as stated previously, the Elementary Remote Academy schedule began on the first day of school, which was September 15th.

[Galusi]: That schedule is how all elementary students in Medford Public Schools began the school year.

[Galusi]: As we all know, we started remotely for a few weeks.

[Galusi]: That schedule has

[Galusi]: really not changed.

[Galusi]: It's been the same schedule that students have been following all along.

[Galusi]: And even the hybrid, the current hybrid schedule is based off of the remote schedule.

[Galusi]: So the consistencies, just to speak about specifically, are that students are attending their virtual school every single day, five days a week, as stated in the previous slide.

[Galusi]: Four of those days, Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday, are mostly synchronous instruction with the teacher.

[Galusi]: The Wednesday is a mixture of both.

[Galusi]: So the students start their morning synchronously with the teacher.

[Galusi]: for about two to three blocks and then finish the day with asynchronous lessons.

[Galusi]: The academic blocks are aligned by grade level and district wide.

[Galusi]: So students in the fourth grade remote learning academy, let's say at the Roberts School, have the same exact schedule as fourth grade students at McGlynn Elementary School.

[Galusi]: That is the consistency through the schools and through the district.

[Galusi]: There have been two small changes to the remote element, to the remote academy.

[Galusi]: The first was we had to add three minutes of transition and transitional time between specialist blocks.

[Galusi]: So specialists meaning art, PE, physical education and technology.

[Galusi]: This allows both the students and the specialists a little bit of transitional time to go from class to class.

[Galusi]: The other change was in order to meet the needs of all students and ensure that every Medford public school student, whether they're in the remote academy or the hybrid learning model, have access to their specialist teachers.

[Galusi]: There may have been a change in the specialist teacher as the hybrid model came to completion.

[Galusi]: The staggered, excuse me, hybrid model came to completion at the elementary level.

[Galusi]: You may go to the next slide, please.

[Galusi]: And this talks a little bit of our enrollment for both learning models.

[Galusi]: So you can see it's coded by school.

[Galusi]: It has all the grade spans listed and it has the enrollment currently for the hybrid and the remote classrooms.

[Galusi]: You'll notice that some schools have one remote learning academy strand and some schools may have two.

[Galusi]: This was based on enrollment numbers, which have ebbed and flowed as we began with the first week of school.

[Galusi]: Requests as mentioned in the dynamic reopening plan that was

[Galusi]: a collaborative approach to planning, which we involved all stakeholders, teachers, administration,

[Galusi]: staff as well as parents and caregivers, we put in that model requests for switching between learning models and it was stated that it's about two weeks prior to the close of each marking period or on a case-by-case basis as needed as we're well aware that certain situations within family dynamics come up and decisions may need to be made sooner than

[Galusi]: two weeks prior to the end of each marking period.

[Galusi]: These two dates are given that are reflected here Friday, December 11 and Friday, March 5 are the two weeks prior to when report cards will be going out and when the formal process for making requests to switching learning models can begin.

[Galusi]: what we would do is we just ask that you get in touch with the school principal and they will talk to you about the process for that.

[Galusi]: Final decisions for any switch in the models are based on staffing and space availability.

[Galusi]: As Dr. Edouard-Vincent mentioned in her opening statements, we have really wanted to make sure that we created models that provide families with,

[Galusi]: as much choice as possible for what is best for their family situation and their children.

[Galusi]: And so based on that, we've been able to provide two learning models and we've tried to work with families on a case by case basis to do what's best

[Galusi]: for the current situation that they are in.

[Galusi]: So if, when those switches are made, the majority of the time it will result in a new teacher and a new set of classmates for that student switching.

[Galusi]: Regardless of the model that students are learning in, whether it's hybrid or remote, classrooms right now cannot exceed about 25 students.

[Galusi]: I will, I know that I believe this is my last slide, but I just want to, yep, thank you very much.

[Galusi]: I just want to reiterate that certain decisions may be, not everyone may agree with some of the decisions in terms of making requests and it involves switching learning models, but I really think it's,

[Galusi]: All decisions made have the best interest of students at heart.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: Yes, there's a second teacher at the Columbus second grade and there's a second teacher at the Brooks third grade.

[Galusi]: I can alter that chart for you to reflect that.

[Galusi]: To be honest, I believe it's a little bit of both.

[Galusi]: Member van de Kloot, I know that right now they're team teaching, but I think in terms of parent communication, report card grading and things like that, they may have,

[Galusi]: factored that down just a little bit more, but I know that it is more of a team, a co-teaching situation at both of those grade levels.

[Galusi]: No, I have not at this moment.

[Galusi]: I think that as I mentioned in the presentation and just to kind of reiterate, first of all, at all levels, both the hybrid and the remote, it's Medford Public Schools employees.

[Galusi]: It's just there may have been a shift for some of the remote academy students that

[Galusi]: they had shifted from their school-based specialists to district-wide Medford public school specialists.

[Galusi]: It was not a unilateral shift.

[Galusi]: So some classrooms, some students were able to retain some of their specialists, but as we staggered in more classrooms at the hybrid, there also was a need to shift some staff around just to make sure that students were receiving

[Galusi]: specialist education from teachers.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: Much agreed.

[Galusi]: I just wanted to mention too that, of course, it's not what we wanted to happen or originally anticipated happening, but it is why we also gave some advanced notice in that shift.

[Galusi]: It was mentioned in the superintendent's Friday memo.

[Galusi]: teachers were well informed about that shift.

[Galusi]: So they were working with the students about two weeks prior to the transition.

[Galusi]: And in some cases, I know that teachers had joined up so that the students were able to kind of put a face to the teacher before that shift happened.

[Galusi]: So.

[Galusi]: I would say it probably is a majority, but not all.

[Galusi]: So in the beginning, there were some instances where that was happening, but we have since been hiring, as the superintendent has mentioned, we've since been hiring monitors for situations such as that.

[Galusi]: And that is not the reason why we had to make that shift.

[Galusi]: Part of the reason why we had to make that shift was for

[Galusi]: not only to make sure every student was able to have a specialist educator and not have asynchronous work, but also for

[Galusi]: When we staggered in based on COVID parameters, based on looking at all of cohort A populations and making sure that cohort numbers did not increase based on the size of the six foot social distancing, there were some situations in which pre-COVID, some of our cohort A students would have been able to integrate with cohort B and C students.

[Galusi]: And in this scenario, they were unable to

[Galusi]: join a cohort B or C class for specialists.

[Galusi]: So there are some situations in which certain cohorts based on enrollment numbers for cohort A had to have their own specialist time, which increased the number of specialist blocks and therefore we had to shift the specialist staff.

[Galusi]: Good morning, Suzanne Galusi, assistant superintendent of schools for the elementary level.

[Galusi]: All right.

[Galusi]: That's a great question, Bill.

[Galusi]: So I want to start by saying that

[Galusi]: The draft dynamic plan is being updated based on community input, educator and administrative input, as well as DESE input.

[Galusi]: So they've reached out to communities and districts to give us feedback on our plan as well.

[Galusi]: So we're in the middle of finalizing all of that so that we can submit it by the end of the week.

[Galusi]: The new deadline for DESE for finalization is this Friday.

[Galusi]: In that updated plan, which the community will see probably Friday, we have put in for some movement within plans.

[Galusi]: So, or excuse me, learning models.

[Galusi]: So we understand that it may not be a fit.

[Galusi]: for students if they started in hybrid or if they started in remote and wanted to move to a different learning model.

[Galusi]: We also know that situations may arise in families where you need to switch models.

[Galusi]: So we have put some language in the updated dynamic plan to reflect that.

[Galusi]: So basically, a family would put a request in.

[Galusi]: and we will look at the logistics of it.

[Galusi]: And the request needs to come in about, we're going to go by the semesters, the marking periods.

[Galusi]: So another piece is that DESE is requiring that all grading is in place and continues.

[Galusi]: So the typical grading systems and report cards will start day one.

[Galusi]: So that kind of lends itself to natural semesters.

[Galusi]: So that's how we're going to be

[Galusi]: switching and taking parent requests at that time.

[Galusi]: So about two weeks before the close of a semester, parents can formally request if they would like their child to have a learning model switch.

[Galusi]: So at the elementary level where there are three report cards and a winter break,

[Galusi]: their date for that first semester is Friday, December 11th, that they would have to put the request in.

[Galusi]: That gives administration and school buildings the time to work on the logistics so that it could go into effect coming back in January.

[Galusi]: At the secondary level, two weeks prior to the first semester close is Monday, November 2nd.

[Galusi]: And then that would go into effect when the new semester starts, which would begin Monday, November 16th.

[Galusi]: All of this is contingent upon capacity.

[Galusi]: So we have to look at numbers and we have to look at balance.

[Galusi]: We also want it to be noted that if a parent is putting in a request for a learning model change,

[Galusi]: that it may include a change in teacher as well as classmates, because those models are not set up to share classmates or educators.

[Galusi]: So that's exactly right.

[Galusi]: The phases right now go for every two weeks to bring in a new group.

[Galusi]: So using the metrics that were supplied to us yesterday by the governor and Commissioner Riley from the Department of Education, in collaboration with Medford's Board of Health,

[Galusi]: will help keep us aligned with our staggered approach.

[Galusi]: So if the metrics are, if the Medford community is still in the unshaded or green color code, then we are able to keep proceeding with our staggered approach.

[Galusi]: Sure, because the schedules will be created for students based on the learning model that they choose.

[Galusi]: So students that are in the hybrid model, whether you're in elementary or secondary level, a schedule is created for you.

[Galusi]: If we are forced to close partway through at any time, we will stay in the hybrid model.

[Galusi]: so that the teachers are the same because the students have already started working with them and a rapport has been set.

[Galusi]: Depending on the length of the closure, the hybrid teachers will remain the same, but the schedule may shift so that

[Galusi]: It's not going to be that your students are receiving two and a half days of virtual instruction and two full days of asynchronous.

[Galusi]: It would mirror a little bit the remote overall schedule.

[Galusi]: Those details are being worked out with the school-based teams right now.

[Galusi]: So Joan Bowen, the Director of Pupil Services, has been working around the clock all summer with many of us to ensure that student needs are taken care of and well thought in terms of scheduling and their IEP needs.

[Galusi]: So IEP needs in a remote situation

[Galusi]: remote learning plans are created in that case so that student needs are taken into account both in person and virtually, depending on what learning model families choose.

[Galusi]: High needs, as Dr. Edouard-Vincent has said many times, includes five protected classes of students.

[Galusi]: If we're specifically talking about students on an IEP, the high needs are for students where

[Galusi]: about 75% of their IEP academic needs encompass the school day.

[Galusi]: So in other words, if during a typical school day, your child has IEP services that equal about 75% of their day, then they are qualified as high needs.

[Galusi]: So what Joan Bowen is working on with her staff diligently is

[Galusi]: is coming up with groupings for students.

[Galusi]: And I would anticipate that you would be hearing something probably in September at some point.

[Galusi]: Right now, our official first day of school is Wednesday, September 16th.

[Galusi]: And so what the school-based teams are working on right now are the schedules and the cohorts and all the fine details that we will be able to share with families in September.

[Galusi]: Exactly right, Tom.

[Galusi]: So we heard this concern a lot when we asked for feedback from families in the community based on how last year's remote experience was.

[Galusi]: And so that consistency piece and also having students create a little bit more ease for access on a lot of the educational platforms and websites that they need to go on

[Galusi]: The district is now going to utilize a system called Clever.

[Galusi]: It is detailed in our dynamic plan and we've even included a link.

[Galusi]: so that if you would like to find out a little bit more about the Clever platform, you can just click that link.

[Galusi]: It'll bring you.

[Galusi]: But what Clever is, is a single stream platform.

[Galusi]: So using this, every student is issued an email address.

[Galusi]: And when the students use their Metro Public Schools email address, they just log on to Clever once.

[Galusi]: And then all of the educational platforms that Metro Public Schools will be using at every level will be housed in Clever.

[Galusi]: And so all students will need to do is click on the icon that they need.

[Galusi]: And so it takes away having to keep and manage all of the individual logons and passwords.

[Galusi]: I think we should just know that we are working on, um, language to inform parents.

[Galusi]: regarding the alphabet and how it will be utilized as part of the daily correspondence with schools.

[Galusi]: That's a great question, but what our intention right now

[Galusi]: Oh, really?

[Galusi]: Yeah.

[Galusi]: I was rolling.

[Galusi]: So we want parents to select the learning plan that works for their family and for their children.

[Galusi]: So it is the intent that Medford public educators will teach either the hybrid learning model or the remote learning model.

[Galusi]: How those teachers will be selected is a decision that needs to be made in collaboration with the teachers association.

[Galusi]: And so we don't have those answers yet.

[Galusi]: in terms of

[Galusi]: high school level courses, the specifics of the scheduling, I'm sorry, we don't have more detail just yet, but the details of the scheduling is what the school-based teams are working on right now.

[Galusi]: And those school-based teams were the second part of this planning phase.

[Galusi]: And so we had to wait until the school committee decision, which was just last Thursday.

[Galusi]: So this is the first week.

[Galusi]: that the school based teams are getting up and running.

[Galusi]: So once we have the specifics on scheduling, we will let the community know.

[Galusi]: Yeah, I think just overall in our timeline, which is reflected in the dynamic plan, the commissioner gave every district in the Commonwealth 10 days so that staff have time to plan, work, collaborate, be professionally developed,

[Galusi]: as well as families that Dr. Cushing mentioned.

[Galusi]: But within those 10 days, we have earmarked three of them for orientation purposes at every level.

[Galusi]: So regardless if your family has chosen the hybrid learning model,

[Galusi]: or the remote learning model, we are going to use those three days to create safe socially distant opportunities, possibly outdoors, for families, so parents and caregivers, as well as children to meet their educators.

[Galusi]: even if you're going remote, we feel that it's extremely important for you to be able to meet in person and start to build that rapport so that you can know someone more than just the pixelated boxes on the computer screen.

[Galusi]: So we will send out, you will probably be hearing from the building-based teams on your schedule for the orientation days.

[Galusi]: Okay.

[Galusi]: Do you want me to go back?

[Galusi]: Okay.

[Galusi]: So just to briefly answer Megan's question, some of those decisions have somewhat been made for us through the Department of Education.

[Galusi]: So they released some standards regarding specialists or fine arts classes.

[Galusi]: So in particular, as of right now, music classes cannot occur indoors.

[Galusi]: So that means either we need to look at having those classes outdoors during in-person hybrid days, or most likely a lot of music education will take place virtually for students.

[Galusi]: The physical education requirements.

[Galusi]: They have given a different set of requirements when you're outdoors.

[Galusi]: So for example, if you have your students engage in a physical education class and you can keep the students six feet or more, if you can keep the students at 10 feet, masks do not need to be worn.

[Galusi]: And those could be opportunities for mask breaks for students.

[Galusi]: But if students are six feet or closer, of course, masks have to be worn even during a physical education class.

[Galusi]: In terms of the other guidance from the Department of Education, it says to try and keep the cohorts with as less movement as possible.

[Galusi]: So what that might mean at the elementary level is that the students remain in the classroom and those specialist teachers rotate into the classrooms.

[Galusi]: And at the secondary level, it just means that they're trying to cluster them so that there's not too much movement.

[Galusi]: but we're also looking at having some of those classes be done virtually.

[Galusi]: Galusi.

[Galusi]: Yes, thank you.

[Galusi]: In closing, I just want to echo what Dr. Edouard Vincent said that, you know, the continued partnership with you is essential moving forward.

[Galusi]: And so everyone on this call here today, Tom, Peter, Maurice, myself, we're all parents as well.

[Galusi]: So we feel, you know, the same things that you're feeling right now and having to make decisions for our own children about next year too.

[Galusi]: And I think it's just important

[Galusi]: for everyone to know that because we're with you.

[Galusi]: And so moving forward to continue that partnership, I think it's very important that you continue to reach out.

[Galusi]: So if there's anything that we can do to help your family with the reopening of schools, please, I urge you to reach out to your school-based principal and you can always reach out to one of us.

[Galusi]: We're here to partner with you and to help you in any way we can.

[Galusi]: so thank you so much we're glad you were able to join us today and we will inform the community in the next week or two about the leveled stream yards that we'll have to answer specific questions about pre-k through elementary and then middle school and high school thank you thank you everybody have a great rest of the day all right and mustangs out

[Galusi]: Alright.

[Galusi]: And do you wanna just clarify the percentage piece that it's the information that the state and even nationally is working on is that the average percent, which reflects that Johns Hopkins chart should be below 5%.

[Galusi]: I think that's just important to note.

[Galusi]: So we're at 1.3, significantly below 5%.

[Galusi]: Right.

[Galusi]: Sure, sure.

[Galusi]: So I think the draft schedule that was in the plan was just like a broad overview of how things could possibly look.

[Galusi]: Wednesday right now has the half day.

[Galusi]: schedule.

[Galusi]: So the next phase of the work that we have to do will be to fine tune and come up with those specific details.

[Galusi]: Now that the school committee has voted for the hybrid and the fully remote plan, now we get some of the task force back together and we have to work on those fine details.

[Galusi]: I don't have a specific answer at this time because we still need people to come back and do that fine detail work.

[Galusi]: The only thing I will say that I've said before is that we want to take a developmental approach to how many hours students are going to be expected to be

[Galusi]: doing live synchronous learning.

[Galusi]: We certainly do not expect kindergartners and first graders to be on the screen for three hours, but high schoolers may be able to handle three hours of online synchronous time.

[Galusi]: So once those specifics are ironed out in the next two weeks, we absolutely will give an update to the community.

[Galusi]: So right now with the, so I'm looking at the next question, it's talking about the class sizes in the remote auction.

[Galusi]: And so right now, as Dr. Cushing had mentioned, the survey is

[Galusi]: still going.

[Galusi]: So we have about 1,700 responses.

[Galusi]: We have to wait and see what those numbers look like in terms of how many families want the remote option fully.

[Galusi]: We also then have to look based on those families where the breakdown is per grade.

[Galusi]: So of course we do not want a remote class to be

[Galusi]: to have high numbers, but it may not have the numbers that a hybrid class would when they're in person.

[Galusi]: But what we would probably frame it on is what is a typical class size of about 20 students.

[Galusi]: But it's going to vary depending on enrollment numbers.

[Galusi]: The next question from Karen, will there be any way of preserving classes- Preserving classes with assigned schools and teams with middle school, or is that all dependent on what families choose and what teachers?

[Galusi]: Yes.

[Galusi]: Perfect.

[Galusi]: But I do, I think it's important to note though, since you brought that up, Dr. Edward-Vincent, that the surveys were sent out translated and we have had several families responding on the translated versions as well.

[Galusi]: And the last count for that was an additional one to 200.

[Galusi]: So unfortunately at this time, that's one of those decisions that we are going to be discussing with the school-based team, as well as some of the working teams.

[Galusi]: So we have had some parents reach out to their building principals with maybe some of their personal needs that they have due to work schedules or family life situation.

[Galusi]: And we would encourage you to still do so.

[Galusi]: But our intent is that we are keeping families together because we know that there is no perfect solution to the world we're living in right now, but we really do want to try to do what's best for families.

[Galusi]: So our intent is to keep families together.

[Galusi]: which includes blended families as well.

[Galusi]: If you have specific needs beyond that, I would suggest that you reach out to your building principal, and we are going to do our best to accommodate.

[Galusi]: But it's definitely going to be a cumbersome logistic puzzle that we are going to be starting to work on at the end of this week, beginning of next week.

[Galusi]: I think it's important to note though too that

[Galusi]: A vocational teacher was assigned to the hybrid group.

[Galusi]: I'm not quite sure what happened, but did not participate in the planning for the group.

[Galusi]: But that's why we, during those task force groups, reached out to Chad Fallon so that we made sure that the vocational voice was heard.

[Galusi]: And that's why the link was embedded in that dynamic plan for both the hybrid and the remote model.

[Galusi]: Yes, yes.

[Galusi]: So if your child is enrolled in the hybrid model and they have their schedule with their set teachers, that will continue if the schools have to then close and go into remote.

[Galusi]: They will continue with the hybrid schedule and educators that they started with.

[Galusi]: Now,

[Galusi]: What they may do is pick up some of the expectations and schedules that are working in the remote model, but their educators will remain the same.

[Galusi]: I hope that answers their question.

[Galusi]: So in other words, depending on how long we may be closed, you may follow the remote schedule so that you will have that balance of synchronous and asynchronous time, but you would keep the educators that you had within the hybrid model.

[Galusi]: So we agree.

[Galusi]: Everyone right here answering these questions and on this StreamYard session, we're all parents.

[Galusi]: We all have more than one child.

[Galusi]: We all know how different they can be as learners and as little people and big people.

[Galusi]: I know I have two completely different students as children.

[Galusi]: You're right, and I think Dr. Edouard-Vincent really spoke about the early childhood piece and how really critical it is because they're still developing those readiness skills.

[Galusi]: And for entering kindergarten, depending on what their

[Galusi]: a preschool experience, if they even had one, was like, they may be coming in with no readiness skills and it's our job to prepare them to be students.

[Galusi]: So we know if we're in a remote situation, we do realize, as previously said, that we don't expect them to be on a computer for three hours a day.

[Galusi]: But the work that's going to start with the teams next week to fine tune these plans,

[Galusi]: is going to have representation from each level.

[Galusi]: That's what we're hoping for in working with the teachers union for that, so that we can specifically target those remote plans to the specific levels, because the expectation for a kindergartener in a remote level is not gonna be what the expectation is for a fourth grader or a fifth grader, and certainly not for middle school and high school.

[Galusi]: So I do apologize that I don't have a more exact specific answer for you, it's coming.

[Galusi]: but it's definitely going to be a developmental approach.

[Galusi]: Sure, I think that's very important.

[Galusi]: I think I'll start there, Tom.

[Galusi]: So we've set aside about three days for like an orientation so that families and students can come and have time in a safely distant way or manner, maybe outdoors to meet their teachers.

[Galusi]: no matter what plan.

[Galusi]: So I know you're specifically asking about hybrid, but that orientation is also going to be for students that are enrolled in the all-remote academy as well.

[Galusi]: And so during the orientation, parents will be given schedules or have an idea of how things may roll out and have the opportunity to, even though it's brief, but have that face-to-face and start the rapport with your child or children's educators.

[Galusi]: during those 10 days that the Department of Education has given each district, we're going to spend time.

[Galusi]: So teachers not only are going to have a lot of time to plan and collaborate for this big undertaking, but they're also going to have some training.

[Galusi]: And it's going to be around the hybrid model, as well as the remote model, as well as the safety precautions and protocols.

[Galusi]: So the hybrid, when the students are in the building,

[Galusi]: We're going to, as close as we can, have it mirror what it's like for them when they're in school.

[Galusi]: Now, granted, there are certain things that aren't going to be the same.

[Galusi]: So desks may not be in clusters.

[Galusi]: They may be separated so that we're keeping the social distancing that we need to keep at six feet.

[Galusi]: If they're science tables, they're going to have to be at each end if that is six feet.

[Galusi]: the school-based teams are going to handle what the schedules look like for transitions in hallways to keep it at a minimum.

[Galusi]: So there'll be a little bit less moving than the secondary students are used to.

[Galusi]: And that also includes like lunch routines and bathroom routines.

[Galusi]: So we know that each building

[Galusi]: is slightly different, and even due to enrollment numbers, a lunch schedule at the Columbus Elementary may look different than at the Roberts Elementary.

[Galusi]: So the school-based teams that have started their work will come out with a more detailed day in the life of or schedule for a hybrid model.

[Galusi]: I can answer, like I know in elementary, lunch will probably take place in the classroom with

[Galusi]: than the students going outside for recess.

[Galusi]: It might look a little different though at the secondary level.

[Galusi]: So we will let you know what the schedule will look like in further detail once the school-based teams have mapped it out.

[Galusi]: Right.

[Galusi]: So thank you.

[Galusi]: So in all of the ways that we have gathered community input regarding their remote experience last year, and through all of the work on the task forces, we heard loud and clear that parents want consistency.

[Galusi]: That was one of the biggest pieces.

[Galusi]: So consistency in the expectations for learning for their students at every level and at every department.

[Galusi]: and consistency with the scheduling.

[Galusi]: So that was what we wanted.

[Galusi]: We really wanted to make sure we covered both of those areas.

[Galusi]: And I think that the sample schedules, though they may change a bit, but those sample schedules really took into account to make sure that we're consistent throughout Metro Public Schools.

[Galusi]: I think that part of the work in the remote group, because of that experience that educators and parents had, we did spend some time talking about what the accountability would look like at the administrative level, at the educator level, and at the parent, caregiver, student level.

[Galusi]: We gave you a little sampling in the dynamic plan.

[Galusi]: Yeah, I like that.

[Galusi]: navigate the remote pieces.

[Galusi]: hope that answered your question.

[Galusi]: Okay, so one of the things that we are also working on is creating a list of terminology that will be helpful for students and families.

[Galusi]: Asynchronous means that they are live or as, excuse me, recorded lessons, or as Mr. Teixeira said, he referred to them as independent learning time.

[Galusi]: So that is asynchronous lessons that teachers have prepared will be blocks of time that are either independent to work on assignments ongoing,

[Galusi]: especially at the secondary level, and it also may include some recorded lessons, either from the teacher or another professional outlet, in order to teach students new material.

[Galusi]: The opposite of that is synchronous, which means live lessons that the teacher does virtually in real time with his or her students.

[Galusi]: And if you had heard in the introductions that Stacey, Joan, and Paul were all involved in the instructional work groups, if either of them want to chime in, another way to explain it, please do.

[Galusi]: If not, hopefully that's helpful.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: So this is one, yes, I was just going to say, I would like to throw this one to Stacey Shulman, because she has that secondary expertise.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: Yeah, and I'm just going to piggyback on that.

[Galusi]: Most of us on this panel are working parents ourselves, so we can truly appreciate the hardship that this puts, this whole situation puts on families.

[Galusi]: And I just felt that that was important to say.

[Galusi]: In terms of the remote model,

[Galusi]: I think part of what Dr. Cushing had said before and part of all the feedback that we've been receiving through various outlets from the community is the need to have the remote model.

[Galusi]: as close as possible mirror a typical school day.

[Galusi]: So the remote situation that you were all thrust into last spring is not going to look the same as we reopen schools in the fall.

[Galusi]: So at every level, we have worked with our teams to create remote schedules that

[Galusi]: as close as we can align to a typical school day.

[Galusi]: So we have, you will see that in our plan, because you can see that we have made sure that we give screen time breaks, but in the same time keep to a schedule that is reflective of a typical school day, starting somewhere, depending on the level, around 8 a.m.

[Galusi]: and finishing somewhere, depending on the level, about 2 p.m.

[Galusi]: Anybody wants to chime in, they can.

[Galusi]: Hopefully that answers your question.

[Galusi]: Yes, correct.

[Galusi]: The buildings, elementary and middle school, although I'm sorry, I really can't speak totally to middle school, but I know the elementary classrooms have a sink in them, not maybe specialist classrooms and not service providers, although art rooms do have a sink in them, so students are able to wash their hands.

[Galusi]: I'm just going to start and then you can go.

[Galusi]: I just wanted to say that this is definitely something in terms of the remote, from starting from the beginning, we do want to make sure that there is a rapport that is created.

[Galusi]: We know it's not going to replicate what typically happens each school year, but we are, as Dr. O'Dwyer-Vincent, I think, already mentioned, we are trying to figure out some

[Galusi]: socially distant, safe outdoor opportunities for students to meet their teachers.

[Galusi]: Before school is a little bit more tricky because the cohorts aren't established, but it is on our radar of things that we are looking to provide if we are back to school in person.

[Galusi]: If it's okay, I just wanted to speak on the elementary level, going with what the superintendent said.

[Galusi]: Part of the closely monitoring is also that some students, in addition to the elements that the superintendent mentioned, also may, at least for my school, may be attending meetings consistently.

[Galusi]: but maybe not doing the work consistently.

[Galusi]: So we're monitoring the academic piece, but the social emotional is definitely the first.

[Galusi]: And just to highlight on your multi-tiered system and to chime in about what the superintendent said, at the elementary level, Stacey Shulman has been working with her staff and they are doing and continuing with lunch bunches virtually so that those students are being targeted and getting the support that they need.

[Galusi]: Thank you.

[Galusi]: Yeah, you're welcome.

[Galusi]: Good evening, that would be me, Suzanne Galussi, Principal of the Brooks.

[Galusi]: The E in our ACES core objectives stands for equity.

[Galusi]: Within education, the term equity means that every student will get what they need.

[Galusi]: Therefore, Medford Public Schools fosters equitable learning environments by understanding the needs of our diverse population and supporting the academic, social, emotional, and physical needs of our students.

[Galusi]: We have four initiatives to address this objective.

[Galusi]: Please remember that these initiatives are a work in progress.

[Galusi]: So the first is to ensure equitable access through the implementation of the multi-tiered system of support and enrichment MTSSE, formerly known as RTI.

[Galusi]: To encompass a growth mindset, this initiative has expanded our focus beyond just RTI, which stands for response to intervention.

[Galusi]: So in other words, an MTSSE system is not just limited to interventions.

[Galusi]: It also focuses on meeting the social, emotional, and physical needs of our learners.

[Galusi]: The second initiative is to use data from ongoing assessments to support teaching and learning in order to close the achievement gap.

[Galusi]: This will be a comprehensive approach within school buildings and throughout the district.

[Galusi]: Promote and enhance the activities and resources that address the needs of the whole child.

[Galusi]: It should be noted that when addressing the needs of the whole child, we're looking at the complete picture of what that means.

[Galusi]: And that will encompass multiple intelligences, athletics, fine arts, et cetera.

[Galusi]: And to promote the health and wellness of students.

[Galusi]: When students are happy and healthy and their needs are met, they're ready to learn.

[Galusi]: And this segues beautifully into our final core value, the S of support, which Susanna Campbell and Stacey Shulman will discuss.

[Galusi]: So MTSSE is like an umbrella?

[Galusi]: And so RTI fits underneath.

[Galusi]: So we're not dropping RTI, but RTI is more academic based, and it focuses on what students need academically.

[Galusi]: We want to think about the whole child, and we also want to have systems in place to address the social, emotional, or physical needs.

[Galusi]: So in addition to RTI.
